author: IT之家
title: 欧盟用户抢先体验：苹果 iOS 18.4 将放开默认导航选项_腾讯新闻
text: IT之家 3 月 13 日消息，科技媒体 MacRumors 昨日（3 月 12 日）发布博文，报道称苹果公司计划在 4 月发布的 iOS 18.4 更新中，针对欧盟地区，放开默认导航应用选项，用户可以根据自身偏好，选择 Apple Maps 之外的地图应用。消息称苹果公司为遵守欧盟《数字市场法》，计划在 iOS 18.4 系统中，放开默认导航地图应用选项。...
topics: Economy, Business and Finance->products and services
Economy, Business and Finance->computing and information technology

author: halrogers.house.gov
title: Congressman Rogers Announces $10 Million Earmark to Expand Morehead State University’s Space Science Network - Press Releases - U.S. Congressman Hal Rogers
text:
Recognizes U.S. Lunar Mission “Saviors” with Congressional Tribute
MOREHEAD, KY (Oct. 17, 2024) – U.S. Rep. Harold “Hal” Rogers (KY-05) visited Morehead State University’s Space Science Center on Thursday to announce a federal earmark totaling nearly $10 million in Community Project Funding to broaden the region’s highly competitive deep space network. The funding will be used to enhance the two space tracking stations on campus to support future government-funded and commercial space programs.
“The staff and students at Morehead State are now involved in some of the United States’ most innovative and historic space missions. This project will allow the space science center to support future NASA programs, including NASA’s Near Space Network, Artemis and the Moon to Mars Program,” said Congressman Rogers, chairman of the House appropriations subcommittee that funds science-related federal agencies . “This means that students here at MSU will have first-hand access to more lunar and deep space tracking services that they cannot get anywhere else in the country.”
“We are incredibly grateful for the support and leadership of Congressman Hal Rogers in securing this critical funding for Morehead State’s Space Science Program. His dedication to advancing science and technology in our region has been instrumental in positioning MSU as a leader in space research and exploration,” said Dr. Jay Morgan, President of Morehead State University . “This funding will allow us to expand our capabilities, provide our students with unmatched hands-on experiences, and contribute to the growing space economy in our region and in Kentucky. It’s an exciting time for Morehead State, and we thank Congressman Rogers for helping make this possible.”
Congressman Rogers also requested a $7.5 million Community Project Funding earmark for fiscal year 2025 MSU’s Space Science Center to provide payload operations for government and commercial space stations. The funding request was approved by the House Appropriations Committee and is pending on-going budget negotiations.
“This funding is a game-changer for Morehead State’s Space Science Program. It enables us to further enhance our research and technological capabilities, allowing our students and faculty to participate in groundbreaking projects that contribute directly to the future of space exploration,” said Dr. Ben Malphrus, Director of the MSU Space Science Center . “We’re deeply thankful to Congressman Hal Rogers for his vision and continued support, which is helping us shape the next generation of space scientists and engineers right here in Eastern Kentucky.”
To highlight the importance of investing in Morehead State’s work at the Space Science Center, Congressman Rogers recognized the staff and students who saved the United States’ latest mission to the moon after a troubled landing damaged the Odysseus Lander, “Odie,” cutting-off communications back to Earth.
“Morehead State was the only conduit between NASA and the private company that sent the lunar lander to the moon to conduct research. The multi-million-dollar mission was in jeopardy of failure, until the staff and students here in our Appalachian Mountains worked around the clock for 72 hours to save that historic mission,” said Congressman Rogers. “I submitted a tribute in the Congressional Record to commemorate the team that NASA Administrator Bill Nelson dubbed as the ‘saviors’ of the nation’s first lunar landing since the Apollo era.”
The Congressional Record is preserved in the Library of Congress, recognizing the work of MSU staff members, Dr. Malphrus, Chloe Hart from Ashland, Emily Walter from Pikeville, Nathan Fite, Christopher Smith and Seifala Moustaffa, as well as students Mila Shearer and Carrie Bruce.
For more information about Congressman Rogers work in Washington and at home in Kentucky, visit halrogers.house.gov and follow him on social media.

author: El Siglo de Torreón
title: Cierran año con aumento de ventas | El Siglo de Torreón
text: Este 2023 ha sido un buen año para los comerciantes laguneros. [lupita cuevas](https://www.google.com/search?as_sitesearch=elsiglodetorreon.com.mx&q=lupita cuevas) Las ventas decembrinas y de fin de año han registrado un leve incremento de un 40 % para los comerciantes que se encuentran en el Mercado Alianza de Torreón. De acuerdo a Pedro Pasillas Mijares, quien es el secretario general del Sindicato de Locatarios, refirió que este 2023 ha sido un buen año para los comerciantes, pues a pesar de que durante el transcurso del año se han registrado algunos incrementos en el costo de alimentos de la canasta básica, la gente ha preferido realizar sus compras en este lugar. Refirió que en el 2022 cayeron drásticamente las ventas a raíz de la contingencia de salud por COVID-19 en el que prácticamente los mismos locatarios absorbieron los aumentos que se dieron en productos como el huevo, que la cartera se llegó a registrar hasta en 85 pesos, en el caso del precio del kilo de tortilla se ofertó hasta en 15 pesos, sin embargo, conforme se ha ido estabilizando la economía en el país, poco a poco la gente ha preferido regresar al mercado a consumir lo local. "El tomate, la cebolla, el chile serrano y la papa, son alimentos que han variado su costo en establecimientos y cadenas comerciales, de los cuales su precio se encuentra sobrevalorado, por ello es de suma importancia que la ciudadanía acuda a realizar sus compras para la cena de fin de año en este lugar, donde se tienen costos accesibles para el bolsillo de los laguneros, además se está contribuyendo en la derrama económica local", asegura. "Con las ventas de fin de año, los comerciantes saben que se tienen que crear estrategias como la de realizar un 'colchoncito' para poder aguantar la cuesta de enero, la cual para nosotros se nos extiende hasta el mes de marzo". Pasillas Mijares dijo que actualmente son 300 locatarios, de los cuales se mantienen 3 mil familias. Finalizó diciendo que para este 1 de enero, se abrirá al público en un horario de 8:00 a 20:00 horas, para que los laguneros puedan adquirir alimentos y materia prima para la elaboración de los platillos, los cuales son de buena calidad, pues es necesario dejar de estereotipar al mercado de manera errónea. EN LERDO Por su parte, locatarios del mercado municipal Donato Guerra en ciudad Lerdo, dijeron que se registran ventas del cien por ciento, por lo que esperan cerrar con "broche de oro". El secretario general de los comerciantes, José Martín Castillo Paredes, manifestó que en todos los establecimiento están registrando mucha afluencia, pero las carnicerías son a quienes les ha ido mejor. En el mercado son unos 50 locales los que hay, y el secretario manifestó que poco más de 40 se encuentran activos; carnicerías, fruterías, tiendas de ropa, fondas, de productos esotéricos y hierberías, reparadoras de calzado, artesanías, locales de venta de ropa de segunda, florerías, queserías, entre otras. El comerciante mencionó que durante estos días llega un gran número de paisanos para festejar con sus familias, por lo que reiteró que esta buena racha les favorece a todos, desde aquellos que ofrecen alimentos, hasta las tiendas de ropa, de regalos o zapatos, por lo que con anticipación se preparan con suficiente mercancía para que sus clientes no se vayan a Gómez Palacio o Torreón. El líder de los comerciantes mencionó que, en toda la zona comercial extienden sus horarios, y cierran hasta las 08:00 de la noche, incluso al igual que el 24, hoy domingo permanecerán hasta atender al último cliente, pues en temporada normal, cierran alrededor de las 03:00 de la tarde.

author: WBIR
title: Ober Mountain elevates experience with new chairlifts, bike park - NewsBreak
text:
1 hours ago GATLINBURG, Tenn. — Ober Mountain, Tennessee's only ski area, has installed two new chairlifts as part of ongoing resort upgrades under new local ownership. The Ober Challenge, a four-person Dopplemayr lift, opened on Jan. 22 and serves multiple ski runs including Ober Chute, Yeti's Run, Grizzly, Mogul Ridge and Bear Run. Read full article
Read in NewsBreak 1

author: Bea Mitchell
title: Security guards at two London museums threaten strike action
text: Outsourced security guards at London’s Science Museum and [Natural History Museum](https://blooloop.com/museum/in-depth/top-museums-in-europe/) are threatening to strike in a dispute over wages. Employed by security contractor Wilson James, the guards who are members of the United Voices of the World (UVW) union are currently balloting for strike action. They are asking for a wage of £16 an hour instead of the planned increase to £13.15, as well as full sick pay from day one of any illness or injury. Currently, the guards earn £11.95 per hour – 51p above the minimum wage, which was the [London](https://blooloop.com/museum/in-depth/top-london-museums/) living wage in 2022. Members of the union say their wages are “stuck in the past” and describe the planned increase as “too little, too late”. Kingsley Ampofo, a security guard at the Natural History Museum, said: “The refusal of Wilson James to offer security guards a decent wage in these harsh economic times is having a serious impact on our wellbeing. “Every member of the museum’s workforce, including the directors, have received a decent rise in their wages. So why not the security guards who work their socks off to ensure the safety of both people and property?” Geoffrey Davis, a security supervisor at the Natural History Museum, said: “The [museums](https://blooloop.com/museum/in-depth/most-visited-museums/) treat us as second class employees when they give their directly employed staff pay rises and bonuses of £500. “We think the museums need to take safety more seriously by treating us the same as their in-house staff, including paying a decent wage and providing sick pay from day one.” Bayo Owolabi, a security guard at the [Science Museum](https://blooloop.com/museum/news/science-museum-cut-ties-equinor-oil-company/), said: “It’s quite disrespectful and demoralising that security guards are the lowest-paid staff in the Science Museum. The other museum staff have received pay rises in line with inflation.” Catherine Campbell, a UVW member and security guard at the Science Museum, added: “I feel demoralised and sad that I’ve not had a proper pay rise.” Members say wages are “stuck in the past” The ballot opened on 6 September and closes on 4 October. If the guards vote to strike, industrial action is expected to take place between 21 October 2024 and 3 April 2025. Petros Elia, general secretary for UVW, said the guards “deserve pay that is fit for the present, not that is stuck in the past”. “The guards, who are mainly migrant workers, are protecting millions of visitors every year and priceless exhibits and artefacts, and they shouldn’t be among the lowest paid workers in the museum,” Elia added. “Wilson James makes millions in profit because of these workers and they need to get with the times and pay them a decent wage.” A Wilson James spokesperson said (via [BBC](https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/articles/c36n6jlz7gro.amp)): “We are actively engaged in conversations with our colleagues and formally recognised trade union representatives at the Science Museum and Natural History Museum and remain dedicated to seeking an effective pay resolution.”
